column7: Findings
Airport: 0% → 100% exposure (Newark's only airport moves entirely into flood zone)
251 of 510 known contaminated sites (49.2%) will be in flood zones by 2050. This represents +152 sites moving into flood zones (154% increase)
Superfund sites: 75% → 100% exposure (all 4 sites will be in flood zones)
Wastewater Treatment: 0% → 100% exposure (city's only facility)

Newark's current flood exposure of 117 assets (15.2%) will increase 157% to 301 assets (39.1%) by 2050, adding 184 facilities to flood zones and more than doubling the city's infrastructure vulnerability.
Findings
Airport: 0% → 100% exposure (Elizabeth's only airport moves entirely into flood zone)
Hospital: 0% → 33.3% exposure (1 of 3 hospitals enters flood zone by 2050)
55 of 118 known contaminated sites (46.6%) will be in flood zones by 2050. This represents +26 sites moving into flood zones (90% increase)
Libraries: 0% → 50% exposure (2 of 4 libraries enter flood zones)
Schools: 1 to 7 exposed, representing a 600% increase—from 2.2% to 15.2% of all schools
Solid Waste Landfills: 57.1% → 100% exposure (all 7 landfills will be in flood zones by 2050)
Superfunds: 0% → 100% exposure (city's only superfund)
Wastewater Treatment: 0% → 100% exposure (city's only facility)

Elizabeth's current flood expsore of 49 assets (20%) will increase by 108% to 102 assets (41.6%) by 2050, adding 53 facilities to flood zones and more than doubling the city's infrastructure vulnerability.
Findings
Powerplants: 42.9% → 85.7% in 2050 (6 out of 7 powerplants will be in flood zones by 2050)
Superfunds: All superfunds are at risk today and will be at risk in 2050
Wastewater treatment: All are at risk today and will be at risk in 2050
Camden's current flood exposure of 113 assets (39.9%) will increase by 27.57% to 144 assets (50.9%) by 2050, adding 31 facilities to flood zones, putting half the city's assets at risk.
Findings
Park: 37.6% → 41.4%, 8 parks at at risk today, and 12 will be in flood zones by 2050
Powerplant: 0 → 50%, half of the powerplants will be in flood zones by 2050
Solid & Hazard: All solid and hazard assets are at risk today, and will be at risk in 2050

Trenton's current flood exposure of 22 assets (13.3%) will increase by 81.95% to 40 assets (24.2%) by 2050, adding 18 facilities to flood zones and more than doubling the city's infrastructure vulnerability.
Findings
Powerplant: 33.3% → 100%, a third of powerplants are at risk today, and all will be in flood zones by 2050
Solid & Hazard: 50% → 100%, half of solid and waste sites are at risk today, and all will be in flood zones by 2050
Solid Waste Landfill: 75% → 100%, 3 out of 4 solid and waste sites are at risk today, and all will be in flood zones by 2050
Superfund: 0% → 100%, all superfund sites will be in flood zones by 2050

Jersey City's current flood exposure of 283 assets (42.1%) will increase by 39.43% to 395 assets (58.7%) by 2050, adding 112 facilities to flood zones, putting more than half of the city's assets at risk.
Findings
Parks: 37.5% → 59.4%, From 2025 to 2050 there is a 58.4% increase in parks that will be in flood zones by 2050 (12 to 19 parks)
Powerplants: 50% of powerplants are at risk today and will be at risk in 2050
Solid and Hazard: 50% of solid and hazard sites are at risk today and will be at risk in 2050

Paterson's current flood exposure of 44 assets (16.2%) will increase by 108.64% to 92 assets (33.8%) by 2050, adding 48 facilities to flood zones and more than doubling the city's infrastructure vulnerability.
Findings
Hospitals: 0 → 100%, By 2050, the only hospital in Asbury Park will be in a flood zone
Known contaminated site: 9.1% → 52.2%, By 2050, there will be a 473.63% increase in exposure for KCS (4 to 23 sites)
Parks: 60% → 100%, 3 out of 5 parks are at risk today and all will be in a flood zone by 2050

Asbury Park City's current flood exposure of 8 assets (12.9%) will increase by 300% to 32 assets (51.6%) by 2050, adding 24 facilities to flood zones and tripling the city's infrastructure vulnerability.
Findings
Hospitals: 85.7%, 6 out of 7 of the city's hospitals are at risk today and will be at risk in 2050
KCS: 93.8% → 99%, All but one of the city's KCS will be in flood zones by 2050, with 90 already at risk today
Libraries: All of the city's libraries are at risk today and will be in flood zones by 2050
Parks: All of the city's parks are at risk today and will be in flood zones by 2050
Powerplants: All of the city's powerplants are at risk today and will be in flood zones by 2050
Schools: 11 out of 12 of the city's schools are at risk today and all will be in flood zones by 2050
Wastewater treatment: All of the city's wastewater treatment sites are at risk today and will be in flood zones by 2050

Atlantic City's current flood exposure of 157 assets (94%) will increase by 4.46% to 164 assets (98.2%) by 2050, adding 7 assets to flood zones and making nearly the entire city's infrastructure vulnerable.
